"Push or pull. Force makes things move. "

The word force comes from Latin fortia, meaning strength. It’s the invisible hand that starts a soccer ball rolling, stops a bike, or crushes a soda can. <[silence:2400]

You feel force every day—when you lift a backpack, slam a door, or even when gravity glues you to the floor. Scientists measure force in newtons (named after Isaac Newton, who first described how forces work). One newton is roughly the weight of a small apple in your hand. <[silence:2400]

Force isn’t just about muscle. A magnet pulls paperclips without touching them. A rocket blasts off because fire pushes down, forcing the ship up. Even a tiny ant carries 50 times its weight—its legs exert force like a forklift. <[silence:2400]

Without force, nothing changes. A parked car stays put until the engine’s force overcomes friction. A diver splashes because gravity’s pull wins over air resistance. <[silence:2400]

Three related subjects are friction’s hidden grip, magnetism’s silent tug, and how levers multiply force.
